Any double quote within a column name must be escaped with two double quotes.

Returns the bit-wise AND of all bits in expr.
Returns the bit-wise OR of all bits in expr.
Returns the bit-wise XOR of all bits in expr.
Returns the population standard deviation of expr (the square root of VAR_POP()). You can also use STD() or STDDEV(), which are equivalent.
Returns the sample standard deviation of expr (the square root of VAR_SAMP().

Returns the population standard variance of expr. It considers rows as the whole population, not as a sample, so it has the number of rows as the denominator. You can also use VARIANCE(), which is equivalent.
Returns the sample variance of expr. That is, the denominator is the number of rows minus one.
The DISTINCT keyword can be used to select all distinct value (the value set) from a column.
The DISTINCT keyword applies to all selected columns, so if more than one column is listed, then the results will be a list of the distinct combinations of all selected columns.
select * from syn123: select distinct foo, bar from syn123

Select all columns from the table identi: The DISTINCT keyword can be used with set functions.  In this example, we will get the count of the distinct values from the foo column.
Perform basic arithmetic.  Supported operators: + | - | /  | *
Perform integer division.
Modulo operation.  Returns the remainder of integer division.
Select all rows where column foo has a value equal to one.
Select all rows where column foo has a string value equal to 'a string', the right-hand-side but be within single quotes (').
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo = 'a string'

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where column foo has a value greater than one.
Select all rows where column foo have a value greater than -1.98e12
Select all rows where column foo has a value  less than one.
Select all rows where column foo has a value that does not equal one.
Select all rows where column foo has a value greater than or equal to one
Select all rows where column foo has a value less than or equal to one.
Select all rows where column foo has a value equal to one, two, or three.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo in (1,2,3)

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where column foo has a value between one and two.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo between 1 and 2

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where column foo has a null value.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo is null

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where column foo has a value that is not null.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo is not null

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where column foo has a value with a prefix of 'bar'.  In this example the right-hand-side of the LIKE keyword is a regular expression where the '%' represents one or more characters or even zero characters.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo like 'bar%'

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where column foo has a value with a prefix of 'bar'.  In this example the right-hand-side of the LIKE keyword is a regular expression where the '_' represents one and only one character.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo like 'bar_'

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where double column foo is not a number or plus or minus infinity
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where isNan(foo) or isInfinity(foo)

Select all columns from the table identi: The default escape character for LIKE regular expression is the '\' character.  In this example we want to find all rows such that foo that contain 'bar_' so we will need to escape the '_' character.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo like 'bar\_'

Select all columns from the table identi: To use a different escape character for LIKE regular expression we must define the escape character.  In this example, the '|' will be used as an escape character instead of '\'.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo like 'bar|_' escape '|'

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where column foo has a value equal to one or column bar has a value equals to two.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo = 1 or bar = 2

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all rows where column foo has a value equal to one and column bar has a value equal to two.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo=1 and bar =2

Select all columns from the table identi: Predicates can be surrounded by the '(' and ')' to enforce precedence and nesting.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where (foo=1 and bar =2) or foobar = 3

Select all columns from the table identi: Filtering on columns of type DATE using a standard string format:  'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS'.  This example selects all rows where column aDate has a value greater than '2017-05-19 22:31:01' (GMT).
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where aDate > UNIX_TIMESTAMP('2017-05-19 22:31:01')*1000

Select all columns from the table identi: Filtering on columns of type DATE using an interval.  This example will select all rows have been modified in last 30 days.  Interval units can be YEAR | QUARTER | MONTH | WEEK | DAY | HOUR | MINUTE | SECOND | MICROSECOND.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where modified_on > unix_timestamp(NOW() - INTERVAL 30 DAY)*1000

Select all columns from the table identi: For columns of type DATE, select the date value as a standard date string in the format: 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS'.

Function to extract a numeric value from a date-time string.  Supported functions include: MICROSECOND | SECOND | MINUTE | HOUR | DAY | WEEK | QUARTER | YEAR | YEARWEEK | DAYOFMONTH | DAYOFWEEK | DAYOFYEAR | WEEKOFYEAR
Function to extract a string value from a date-time string.  Supported functions include: DATE | DAYNAME | MONTHNAME
Concatenate the values of columns foo and bar into a single string.
Replace all space characters with underscores for all values from the foo column.
Convert all string values from the column foo to upper case.
Convert all string values from the column foo to lower case.
Trim leading and trailing white space characters from all string values of the column foo.
Select all rows grouping first by foo, then by bar.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 group by foo, bar

Select all columns from the table identi: Grouping can be used in conjunction with aggregation function.  In this example, values from the foo column are first grouped, then the average of each group is calculated. For this example, one row will be returned for each group.
select * from syn123: select foo, avg(foo) from syn123 group by foo

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all columns from the table with the returned row order sorted by the values of the foo column in ascending order.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 order by foo asc

Select all columns from the table identi: Select all columns from the table with the returned row order sorted by the values of the foo column in descending order.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 order by foo desc

Select all columns from the table identi: Multiple columns can be include in the order by clause.  In this example, the returned row order will be sorted first by foo in ascending order followed by bar in descending order.
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 order by foo asc, bar desc

Select all columns from the table identi: Pagination is used to limit the number of results returned in a single request.  In this example, we want the first ten rows that match our query.
If the above query fetches the first page of ten results with indices from zero to nine, the second page of ten rows can be fetched using this query.
The OFFSET element is optional.  In this example, LIMIT is used to limit the results to the first 5 rows.
Pagination parameters should always be at the end of the query
select * from syn123: select * from syn123 where foo =1 group by bar limit 100 offset 0

Select all columns from the table identi: Every table has at least two reserved columns ROW_ID and ROW_VERSION.  The values for these column are automatically managed and can not be directly modified.  However, these columns can be used in queries like any other column.  In this example, we are selecting all columns for a single row using its ROW_ID.

In this example we are listing all rows that have a current version number greater than 12.  Note: while each row can have multiple versions, only the current version of each row will appear in the index used to support table queries.  That means it is not possible to list old version of a row or select a row using an old version number.
